Today’s Learning Objectives

• Overview of the Title V Needs Assessment Process

• Gain a better understanding of the Ten Public Health Essential

Services Framework
Services Framework

• Review the guidelines for the 2010-2014 Local Needs Assessment

needs assessment

Title V Maternal and Child Health Block Grant
Title V Maternal and Child Health Block Grant

• Primary source of federal support for improving the health and well-
• Primary source of federal support for improving the health and well-

being of mothers and children
being of mothers and children

• Title V MCH Block Grant reporting requirements mandate completion of an annual report/application that specifies: – needs of the State MCH population – programs and policies implemented to meet those needs – monitor progress toward achieving federal and state performance
• Title V MCH Block Grant reporting requirements mandate
completion of an annual report/application that specifies:
– needs of the State MCH population
– programs and policies implemented to meet those needs
– monitor progress toward achieving federal and state performance

outcome measures
outcome measures

– management/expenditure of funds
– management/expenditure of funds

• Every five years a comprehensive statewide needs assessment
• Every five years a comprehensive statewide needs assessment

must be conducted of the MCH population
must be conducted of the MCH population

Needs Assessment Conceptual Framework
Needs Assessment Conceptual Framework

• Decentralize statewide needs assessment process by
• Decentralize statewide needs assessment process by

having each local jurisdiction conduct a needs assessment
having each local jurisdiction conduct a needs assessment

• Key Goals
• Key Goals

1. Build local jurisdiction needs assessment capacity 2. Obtain extensive stakeholder input at the local level Identify “needs” that may have been missed by only 3. analyzing state level information
1. Build local jurisdiction needs assessment capacity
2. Obtain extensive stakeholder input at the local level
Identify “needs” that may have been missed by only
3.
analyzing state level information

4. Focus local MCAH efforts by having each jurisdiction
4. Focus local MCAH efforts by having each jurisdiction

identifying priority areas they will focus on during the next five years
identifying priority areas they will focus on during the next
five years

Major MCAH Needs Assessment Components
Major MCAH Needs Assessment Components

• Have local jurisdictions conduct a needs assessment
• Have local jurisdictions conduct a needs assessment

• State Title V Agency summarize local level needs and priorities – Provide summary to local jurisdictions and stakeholders
• State Title V Agency summarize local level needs and priorities
– Provide summary to local jurisdictions and stakeholders

• Analyze both local jurisdiction qualitative information and
• Analyze both local jurisdiction qualitative information and

statewide quantitative epidemiologic data
statewide quantitative epidemiologic data

• Assess State Title V Agency capacity
• Assess State Title V Agency capacity

Involve external stakeholders, state administrators, and State Title V agency staff in the prioritization of needs
Involve external stakeholders, state administrators, and State
Title V agency staff in the prioritization of needs

• Obtain public input on needs assessment report
• Obtain public input on needs assessment report

Focus of Needs Assessment
Focus of Needs Assessment

• 2005-2009 Needs Assessment
• 2005-2009 Needs Assessment

– Capacity assessment conducted, but major focus was on
– Capacity assessment conducted, but major focus was on

identifying MCAH population needs and establishing priorities.
identifying MCAH population needs and establishing priorities.

• 2010-2014 Needs Assessment
• 2010-2014 Needs Assessment

– Review and update as needed identification of MCAH population
– Review and update as needed identification of MCAH population

needs and priorities
needs and priorities

– Major focus will be on assessing local and State MCAH program capacity to carry out the delivery of the 10 essential public health services to the MCAH population
– Major focus will be on assessing local and State MCAH program
capacity to carry out the delivery of the 10 essential public health
services to the MCAH population

• Identify gaps and ways to address the gaps • Identify areas of strength, including where we can coordinate and

• Articulate to decision-makers the status of MCAH public health
• Articulate to decision-makers the status of MCAH public health

maximize resources
maximize resources

Essential Public Health Services
Essential Public Health Services

• Developed by the Core Public Health Functions Steering Committee (1994) • Used as a foundation for the National Public Health Performance Standards Program (NPHPSP) instruments
• Developed by the Core Public Health
Functions Steering Committee (1994)
• Used as a foundation for the National
Public Health Performance Standards
Program (NPHPSP) instruments

• Provides a foundation for any public
• Provides a foundation for any public

health activity
health activity

Essential Services of Public Health
Essential Services of Public Health

• Monitor health status • Diagnose and investigate • Inform, educate, and empower • Mobilize community partnerships • Develop policies and plans • Enforce laws and regulations • Link people to needed services / assure care • Assure a competent workforce • Evaluate health services • Research
• Monitor health status
• Diagnose and investigate
• Inform, educate, and empower
• Mobilize community partnerships
• Develop policies and plans
• Enforce laws and regulations
• Link people to needed services / assure care
• Assure a competent workforce
• Evaluate health services
• Research

Assessment Guidelines 2010-2014

Assessment report
Assessment report

• Bonus Feature: The Making Of…

Needs Assessment: Definition
Needs Assessment: Definition

– Systematic collection and examination of information to make decisions to formulate a plan for the next steps leading to public health action (CDC) • Inclusiveness of process • Rigor of data collection and analyses • Integration of findings
– Systematic collection and examination
of information to make decisions to
formulate a plan for the next steps
leading to public health action (CDC)
• Inclusiveness of process
• Rigor of data collection and analyses
• Integration of findings

Top Ten Reasons for Conducting a Needs Assessment
Top Ten Reasons for Conducting a Needs
Assessment

10: Conducting a Needs Assessment is fun (yeah, right!). 9: You like waking up in the middle of the night and the 2010-2014
10: Conducting a Needs Assessment is fun (yeah, right!).
9: You like waking up in the middle of the night and the 2010-2014

Needs Assessment Guidelines is an excellent late-night reading material.
Needs Assessment Guidelines is an excellent late-night reading
material.

8: Local MCAH Directors who conduct a local Needs Assessment are really smart, solve problems and love chocolate. At least one is correct for any given time.
8: Local MCAH Directors who conduct a local Needs Assessment
are really smart, solve problems and love chocolate. At least
one is correct for any given time.

7: It will look good on your resume. 6. Your local Needs Assessment report will impress your
7: It will look good on your resume.
6. Your local Needs Assessment report will impress your

colleagues in other agencies, departments and divisions.
colleagues in other agencies, departments and divisions.

5: It will help you pass any programmatic audit. 4: You get an opportunity to meet colleagues and network. 3: It provides an opportunity to collaborate. 2: To understand the state of the art as MCAH moves to core
5: It will help you pass any programmatic audit.
4: You get an opportunity to meet colleagues and network.
3: It provides an opportunity to collaborate.
2: To understand the state of the art as MCAH moves to core

public health functions.
public health functions.

1: To provide a clear, evidence-based guidance for strategic
1: To provide a clear, evidence-based guidance for strategic

planning and allocating resources in the next five years.
planning and allocating resources in the next five years.

needs assessment

Sector Represented – Code Description A State/local health department (internal partner within agency) B Other state/local agency (Social Services, Education, Justice, Board of Supervisors) C Health provider (dentist, nurse, doctor, nutritionist, counselor, promotora, outreach worker) D Individual or family (community member unaffiliated with any organized community agency) E Community-based organization (local, non-profit organizations) F State or nationally affiliated non-profit organization (local chapter of MOD, ACS, foundation) G School, academia (PTA, School Board, university) H Professional organization/association (AMA, ADA, ACOG, etc.) I Faith-based organization (ministry, church group) J Other (trade and business sector, media and communications, marketing)

J Other (trade and business sector, media and communications, marketing)

mCAST-5 Guidelines: Reminders
mCAST-5 Guidelines: Reminders

– Keep in mind:
– Keep in mind:

• This is a self-assessment • There are no right or wrong answers • You are not being scored • The value of the mCAST-5 lies in the discussion it stimulates and to inform state and federal MCAH of the impact of cuts to MCAH

• There are no right or wrong answers
• You are not being scored

• The process of rating capacity is to get you thinking about your system’s strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats which will inform your SWOT analysis
